techniques.name: Power Chords
techniques.description: Essential power chord progressions in E-A-B pattern

details.musicalFunction: Provides harmonic foundation with aggressive rock sound
tips: Focus on clean transitions between chord shapes
Use consistent palm muting for tight sound

techniques.name: Australian Rock Strumming
techniques.description: Classic pub rock strumming pattern with emphasis and palm muting

details.musicalFunction: Creates driving rhythm characteristic of Australian rock
tips: Palm muting on verses for dynamic contrast
Keep right hand loose and relaxed

techniques.name: Pentatonic Lead Guitar
techniques.description: E major pentatonic-based lead guitar work

details.musicalFunction: Melodic lead lines over the power chord progression
tips: Master the box pattern at 12th fret first
Focus on bending and vibrato technique
Listen to original for phrasing ideas

techniques.name: Palm Muting Dynamics
techniques.description: Alternating between palm muted and open chord sections

details.musicalFunction: Creates dynamic contrast between verse and chorus sections
tips: Use palm muting for verses to create buildup
Open strumming for choruses adds energy
Consistency is key for good dynamics

sections.name: Intro Riff
sections.description: Opening guitar riff establishing the E major tonality with power chord foundation

riffAnalysis.musicalFunction: Establishes key and Australian rock feel

notes: Start with strong E5 power chord attack
Use palm muting for percussive effect

sections.name: Verse
sections.description: Main verse progression with E-A-E-B-E pattern using classic Australian rock rhythm

riffAnalysis.technique: Power chord progression with palm muting

notes: Use palm muting for dynamic control

sections.name: Chorus
sections.description: Main chorus with open chord voicings for bigger sound and energy

riffAnalysis.technique: Full chord voicings instead of power chords
riffAnalysis.musicalFunction: Creates dynamic lift and energy for chorus

notes: Open up palm muting for bigger sound

sections.name: Guitar Solo
sections.description: E major pentatonic-based guitar solo showcasing Australian rock lead style
notes: Use bending and vibrato for expression

guitar.pickup: Humbuckers (bridge for lead, neck for rhythm)

effects.other: None required - focus on natural tube tone

beginner.title: Power Chord Foundations
steps: Learn E5, A5, and B5 power chord shapes
Work on clean chord transitions between E5-A5-B5
Add palm muting technique to verse sections
Play along with simplified rhythm track
beginner.goals: Master basic power chord progression and strumming

intermediate.title: Australian Rock Rhythm
steps: Add dynamic contrast between verse and chorus
Learn the intro riff with proper timing
Work on consistent strumming patterns throughout
intermediate.goals: Play complete rhythm guitar parts with dynamics

advanced.title: Lead Guitar Mastery
steps: Learn E major pentatonic scale patterns
Work on bending and vibrato techniques
Master lead guitar phrasing over the progression
Combine rhythm and lead playing for complete performance
advanced.goals: Master lead guitar work and complete song performance

sameArtist.title: Am I Ever Gonna See Your Face Again
sameArtist.similarity: Similar Australian rock style and power chord usage

similarTechniques.title: Highway to Hell
similarTechniques.similarity: Classic Australian hard rock with similar power chord progressions

similarTechniques.title: Rockin' All Over the World
similarTechniques.similarity: Excellent for practicing power chord fundamentals

similarTechniques.title: Wild Thing
similarTechniques.similarity: Simple progression for beginners learning E-A-B changes

sameGenre.title: Bad Boy for Love
sameGenre.similarity: Same era Australian pub rock with comparable techniques

commonMistakes: Rushing the chord changes - keep steady tempo
Inconsistent palm muting - practice muted vs open contrast
Poor string muting - ensure clean power chord voicings
Overplaying the lead parts - focus on melodic phrasing
practiceRoutine: Work on palm muting with single chords first
Finger exercises for pentatonic scale patterns
Use metronome to maintain steady 132 BPM tempo
focusAreas: Pentatonic scale fluency for lead work
metronomeWork: Focus on tight rhythm section feel

metadata.learningValue: Excellent for power chord mastery and Australian rock style
